docs.abstract: If you suspect your significant other has an unfair advantage, what should you do?
docs.snippet: If you suspect your significant other has an unfair advantage, what should you do?
docs.lead_paragraph: Nathan writes: My girlfriend bought me a step-tracking device so we could challenge each other to see who takes the most steps each week. I’ve discovered that she wears her device while doing laundry, and the device counts her folding activity as steps even though in reality she’s sitting on the couch watching “The Tick.” I request that she take off her device while not engaging in actual steps, in order to make the contest fair.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Step-Tracking Competitions

docs.abstract: Like the best children’s literature, Robert Louis Stevenson’s novel looks to lure young readers into the adult world, not to cosset them from it.
docs.snippet: Like the best children’s literature, Robert Louis Stevenson’s novel looks to lure young readers into the adult world, not to cosset them from it.
docs.lead_paragraph: I was only 5 when I was first exposed to “Treasure Island.” It’s hard to imagine anyone publishing such a book for children today. Jim Hawkins, the story’s boy hero, shoots a pirate — who’s climbing up a rigging after him with a knife in his mouth — point-blank with a pair of pistols. Long John Silver, the story’s most fabled character, hurls his crutch at the back of an innocent shipmate, knocking him to the ground — then hops over to stab the man with a knife. Before it is over, various other characters are shot, stabbed, thrown overboard and run down by horses. Most of them have it coming.

docs.abstract: Peter Andreas’s new book draws from an impressive and eclectic mix of sources to give psychoactive and addictive drugs a fuller place in the history of conflict.
docs.snippet: Peter Andreas’s new book draws from an impressive and eclectic mix of sources to give psychoactive and addictive drugs a fuller place in the history of conflict.

docs.abstract: California is giving a second chance to thousands of inmates who had no hope of parole. But first they have to prove to a panel of strangers that they’ve truly changed.
docs.snippet: California is giving a second chance to thousands of inmates who had no hope of parole. But first they have to prove to a panel of strangers that they’ve truly changed.
docs.lead_paragraph: James Morgan woke up shortly before 4 on the morning of April 19, 2018, and sat on the edge of his bunk, trying to force himself to eat a doughnut. A wiry man with a shaved head, a neat mustache and an eager smile, Morgan was an inmate in a medium-security wing of Solano State Prison in Vacaville, Calif., and he had been preparing for this morning for almost five years, setting aside sports and recreation to make time for work, prayer, study and introspection. Now, sitting in the half-light of his prison dormitory room, he found he could barely swallow. Back when he was 25 and facing a life sentence for attempted murder, he had been too frightened to speak at his trial. But he was 47 now and hoping he would finally find his voice.

headline.main: Can You Talk Your Way Out of a Life Sentence?
headline.print_headline: How to Get Out Of Prison

headline.main: Behind the Cover: The M.B.Z. Moment

docs.abstract: Susan Barba's poem echoes our current moment and offers relief, strongly suggesting we not let the anger overtake us.
docs.snippet: Susan Barba's poem echoes our current moment and offers relief, strongly suggesting we not let the anger overtake us.
docs.lead_paragraph: Susan Barba’s second book, “geode,” is rich with shining interiors and tactile relationships, delicate human to delicate earth, small delusions of ownership against wider backdrops of loss and time. Poems acting as guides, helping us navigate and remember, create an intricate overlay of worlds, humans and trees. This poem — bearing words like “testify” and “judge” — echoes our current moment and offers relief. The title itself is a strong suggestion: We have to keep working at not letting the anger overtake us, hold on too long. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

byline.original: By Susan Barba and Naomi Shihab Nye

docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what to do when a friend dumps his partner after their baby is born and more.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what to do when a friend dumps his partner after their baby is born and more.
docs.lead_paragraph: My husband and I recently learned that friends of ours — let’s call them Tim and Jane — are separating. They have a baby and had a child who died several years ago, in a sudden and devastating way.

headline.main: Can We Stay Friends  With Someone Who Betrayed His Pregnant Partner?
